body_html:
Thinking about what @Mistobaan has commented, that would be a better option, we can specify on the README.md how to compile using bazel and install the libraries, execute the go get and that's it. This makes more sense since the go generate will not be necessary and we are not doing any magic without the users knowledge.

The pros are:

  1. The developer is the one who will install the libs and he will be aware of what he is doing.
  2. It is multi-platform, since right now we are placing the libs on /usr/lib, on the docu we are going to specify "your ld library path".
  3. It makes the package go-gettable.

Cons:

  1. It makes necessary to manually clone the repo, execute bazel and copy the .so, the other option is just copy and paste that line. But this shouldn't be a problem for a developer.

I'm going to update the docu today and remove the library generation.

body:
Thinking about what @Mistobaan has commented, that would be a better option, we can specify on the README.md how to compile using bazel and install the libraries, execute the go get and that's it. This makes more sense since the `go generate` will not be necessary and we are not doing any magic without the users knowledge.

The pros are:
1. The developer is the one who will install the libs and he will be aware of what he is doing.
2. It is multi-platform, since right now we are placing the libs on `/usr/lib`, on the docu we are going to specify "your ld library path".
3. It makes the package go-gettable.

Cons:
1. It makes necessary to manually clone the repo, execute bazel and copy the `.so`, the other option is just copy and paste that line. But this shouldn't be a problem for a developer.

I'm going to update the docu today and remove the library generation.
